Each model is a Python class that subclasses django.db.Model . Each attribute of the model represents a database field. With all of this, Django gives you an automatically-generated database-access API. The most important part of a model is the list of database fields it defines. Fields are specified by class attributes. Be careful not to choose field names that conflict with the models API like clean , save , or delete. The default form widget will be a select box instead of the standard text field and will limit choices to the choices given. The display value for a field with choices can be accessed using the get_FOO_display() method. The default value for the field can be a value or a callable object. If you don’t specify primary_key=True, Django will automatically add an IntegerField to hold the primary key. Each model requires exactly one field to have primary_key=True (either explicitly declared or automatically added) Each field type, except for ForeignKey , ManyToManyField and OneToOneField , takes an optional first positional argument – a verbose name. ForeignKey requires a positional argument: the class to which the model is related. To define a many-to-many relationship, use ManyToManyField . You use it just like any other Field type: by including it as a class attribute of your model. It requires a positional argument: the class to which the model is related. For example, if a Pizza has multiple Topping objects – that is, a Topping can be on multiple pizzas and each pizza has multiple toppings – here’s how you’d represent that: from django.db import models class Topping ( models . Model ): # ... toppings = ManyTo manyField ( Topping ) Django allows you to specify the model that will be used to govern the many-to-many relationship. You can then put extra fields on the intermediate model. The intermediate model is associated with the ManyToManyField using the through argument. You can create many-to-many relationships by creating instances of the intermediate model. You must also specify through_fields as above, or a validation error will be raised. You can also use add() , create() , or set() to create relationships, as long as you specify through-defaults. Once you have established the many-to-many relationships, you can issue queries. For example, to find all the Beatles that joined after 1 Jan 1961 you can query using the attributes of the model. You can also use OneToOneField to define a one- to-one relationship. Django places some restrictions on model field names. A field name cannot be a Python reserved word, because that would result in a Python syntax error. Field name cannot contain more than one underscore in a row, due to Django’s query lookup syntax. The model instance reference has a complete list of methods automatically given to each model. You can override most of these – see overriding predefined model methods , below. There’s another set of model methods that encapsulate a bunch of database behavior that you’ll want to customize. Model inheritance in Django works almost identically to the way normal class inheritance works in Python. There are three styles of inheritance that are possible in Django. Overridden model methods are not called on bulk operations. You can use pre_delete and/or post_delete signals.  abstract base classes are useful when you want to put some common information into a number of other models. You write your base class and put abstract=True in the Meta class. This model will then not be used to create any database table. Instead, when it is used as a base class for other models, its fields will be added. If you are using related_name or related_query_name on a ForeignKey or ManyToManyField, you must always specify a unique reverse name and query name for the field. This would normally cause a problem in abstract base classes, since the fields on this class are included into each of the child classes. Each installed application name must be unique and the model class names within each app must also be unique. Django. model inheritance is when each model in the hierarchy is a model all by itself. Each model corresponds to its own database table and can be queried and created individually. The inheritance relationship introduces links between the child model and each of its parents (via an automatically-created OneToOneField ). When using multi-table inheritance, a new database table is created for each subclass of a model. Django will automatically create a OneToOneField linking your child class back to any non-abstract parent models. You tell Django that it’s a proxy model by setting the proxy attribute of the Meta class to True.  proxy models inherit Meta attributes in the same way as regular models. There is no way to have Django return a MyPerson object whenever you query for Person objects. A proxy model can inherit from any number of abstract model classes providing they do not define any model fields. Multiple inheritance is possible in Django. It’s possible for a Django model to inherit from multiple parent models. The main use-case where this is useful is for “mix-in” classes. Model managers are inherited from abstract base classes. Overriding an inherited field which is referenced by an inherited Manager may cause subtle bugs. See custom managers and model inheritance for more information. The Django Project is managed by a team of volunteers pursuing three goals: Driving the development of the Django web framework, Fostering the ecosystem of Django-related software, Leading the Django community in accordance with the values described in the Django Code of Conduct. The Django Software Foundation handles financial and legal matters related to the Django Project. The steering council selects Mergers as necessary to maintain their number at a minimum of three. There is no upper limit to the number of Mergers. A person may serve in the roles of Releaser and Merger simultaneously. Releasers build Django releases and upload them to the Python Package Index and to the djangoproject.com website. The steering council is a group of experienced contributors who: provide oversight of Django’s development and release process. They assist in setting the direction of feature development and releases, select Mergers and Releasers, and have a tie-breaking vote when other decision-making processes fail. Their main concern is to maintain the quality and stability of the Django Web Framework. A new council is elected after each release cycle of Django. The election process works as follows: The steering council directs one of its members to notify the Secretary of the Django Software Foundation, in writing, of the triggering of the election. As soon as the election is announced, the DSF Board begin a period of voter registration. The five candidates with the highest vote totals immediately become the new steering council.
